Metadata: Influence of El Nino 1997-1998 on the Pelagic Ecosystem off California: Remote-Sensed Analysis
"California and the World Ocean '02 Proceedings," American Society of Civil Engineers (ed.), poster presentation, pp. 1233-1252, Santa Barbara, California, October 27-30, 2002.
Asce & American Society of Civil Engineers.

The influence of the 1997.1998 El Ni�o event on coastal California was evaluated via multidisciplina​ry analysis of remote-sensed data. We processed and analyzed the time-series of surface chlorophyll concentration, sea surface temperature, and wind stress in eight small regions off Central and Southern California. Seasonal summer minima of remote-sensed chlorophyll concentration were observed in all zones of the region under study during the entire periods of observations (1978.1986 for CZCS and 1997.2000 for SeaWiFS), suggesting that nutrient limitation is regulated by the strength and depth of the seasonal pycnocline. Seasonal maxima of chlorophyll were observed during summer in zones of upwelling, during spring in the regions adjacent to upwelling zones, and during winter in the southern area, far from upwelling zones. The main factors stimulating the growth of phytoplankton biomass were the intensity of coastal upwelling and wind stress. The 1997.1998 El Ni�o event resulted in complete collapse of the squid fishery. This collapse was preceded by a significant decrease in remote-sensed phytoplankton biomass. Sea surface temperature increased first in the Southern California Bight and then in the more northern upwelling zones without significant changes of wind pattern. The variations observed during the El Ni�o event were consistent with a deepening of the pycnocline resulting from downwelling waves propagating northward along the coast. This excess stratification likely results in reduced nutrient flux into the euphotic zone; however, the precise mechanism that lead to collapse of the squid fishery requires further investigation.
